answers.answer: I have PCOS I was diagnosed 3 years ago now and I'm not considered high risk although a cyst did rupture when I was around 5weeks. Im currently 36+4 and haven't any problems since then.
I have pcos and my baby girl and me are just fine and healthy no issues at all I'm 23 weeks now
My sister was diagnosed with it six years ago and has a perfectly healthy 4 year old :)

I have PCOS and have a healthy 2 yr old I had no problems with the my pregnancy though he did come at exactly 37 weeks.I'm 35 weeks with my second little boy and though I've had a rougher pregnancy it hasn't been serious issues just more uncomfortable this time.  They do think I may go a little early close to the 37 week mark again (technically not early but close to it).  Neither of my docs have considered me high risk.
I have it. Baby girl and I are absoloutly fine.

I already have two, this is my third. But I was just diagnosed with it back in march. Did you girls have to have help? Like clomid and things? Or did it just happen like mine? And do you ladies have insulin resistance with it?

I was on birth control, threw up one pill and got pregnant. Not planned it just happened. My ultrasound tech said she is a miracle baby. Between the PCOS and birth control she really shouldn't have been concieved. I am not considered high risk but I do have placenta previa.

I was tested to see if i was insulin resistant(thank god) it was negative. I already have a little girl (before PCOS)with this pregnancy I had 1 round of Clomid and it worked for me. I know of other cases where it hasn't though.

I was diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome in september last yr and 3 months later i got pregnant. i had 2 different scares with preeclampsia but havent officially been diagnosed even tho i do have high blood pressure. my ob doesnt have me at high risk and im being induced monday at 39+1.

question: How many of you have PCOS? I  am just wondering how many of you are going through the same thing and is your doctor considering you high risk?Here are some interesting statistics i have found:PCOS patients have a 65% chance of miscarriage vs non PCOS a 45% chance of Gestational Diabetes and Pre EclampsiaHow does PCOS affect a woman while pregnant?Women with PCOS appear to have higher rates of:MiscarriageGestational diabetesPregnancy-induced high blood pressure (preeclampsia)Premature deliveryBabies born to women with PCOS have a higher risk of spending time in a neonatal intensive care unit or of dying before, during, or shortly after birth.
title: pregnant with PCOS?
